Introduction

This policy sets out the statutory requirements for the Mid and South Essex (MSE) Hospitals Group to discharge its appropriate accountability for Safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk of harm or abuse. This document should be read in conjunction with: the relevant NHS England policies relating to safeguarding of individuals; The Southend Essex and Thurrock (SET) Interagency Child Protection & Safeguarding Procedures (2019); Working Together to Safeguard Children (DCSF 2018) ;What to Do If You Are Worried a Child Is Being Abused (SFES 2006) Working Together to Safeguard Children (2018) is particularly informed by the requirements of the Children's Acts (1989/2004), which provide a comprehensive framework for the care and protection of children and underpin the Every Child Matters Change for Children Program (2003).
Policy Aims
Clearly set out the legal framework for safeguarding as it relates to this organisation(s) in order to support them in discharging their statutory requirements to safeguard children and adults.

Outline principles, attitudes, expectations and ways of working that recognise that safeguarding is everybody's business and that the safety and well-being of those in vulnerable circumstances is at the forefront of our business.
We believe that:

Children and young people should never experience abuse of any kind and that we have a responsibility to promote the welfare of all children and young people, to keep them safe and to practise in a way that protects them.
We recognise that:
The welfare of the child is paramount;
All children, regardless of age, disability, gender reassignment, race, religion or belief, sex, or sexual orientation have a right to equal protection from all types of harm or abuse;
Some children are additionally vulnerable because of the impact of previous experiences, their level of dependency, communication needs or other issues;
Working in partnership with children, young people, their parents, carers and other agencies is essential in promoting young people's welfare.
We will seek to keep children and young people safe by:
Valuing, listening to and respecting them;
Adopting child protection and safeguarding best practice through our policies, procedures and code of conduct for staff and volunteers;
Providing effective management for staff and volunteers through supervision, support, training and quality assurance measures;
Recruiting staff and volunteers safely, ensuring all necessary checks are made;
Recording and storing information professionally and securely;
using our safeguarding procedures to share concerns and relevant information with agencies who need to know, and involving children, young people, parents, families and carers appropriately;
Using our procedures to manage any allegations against staff and volunteers appropriately;
Ensuring that we have effective complaints and whistleblowing measures in place.
Scope
This policy sets out the key principles that all staff and workers working across MSE should be complying with safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk of harm or abuse.
All staff carrying out the business of MSE needs to be aware of the integrated agenda to support vulnerable children, young people and adults at risk, in particular those in need of protection.

The MSE group commits to provide line management support and opportunities for learning and development, to ensure that employees have the skills they need to perform their duties and to succeed in their role.

This policy applies to all employees and workers of the MSE group, including seconders into and out of the organisation, volunteers, students, honorary appointees, trainees, contractors, and temporary workers, including locum doctors and those working on a bank or agency contract.
For ease of reference, all employees and workers who fall under these groups will be uniformly referred to as “staff” in this document.
Definitions

table_items.text: In this policy, as in the Children Act 1989 and 2004, a child is anyone who has not reached their 18th birthday. ‘Children' therefore means children and young people throughout.

Is a part of safeguarding and promoting welfare; it refers to the activity taken to protect a child at risk of significant harm. Safeguarding and protecting the welfare of children Protecting children from maltreatment. Preventing impairment of children's health or development and ensuring children are growing up in circumstances consistent with the provision of safe and effective care.
Children defined under Section 17 of The Children's Act (1989)

as those whose vulnerability is such that they are unlikely to reach or maintain a satisfactory level of health or development, or their health or development would be significantly impaired without the provision of services. Disabled children are also included in this category (The Children's Act (1989) S17d).

The term Children Looked After (Children in Care) has a specific legal meaning based on the Children Act, 1989. A child is looked after by a local authority if he or she has been provided with accommodation for a continuous period of more than 24 hours, in the circumstances set out in Sections 20 and 21 of the Children Act, 1989, or is placed in the care of a local authority by virtue of an order made under part IV of the Act.

The MSE Group work within the nationally agreed definition of CSE: Child sexual exploitation is a form of child sexual abuse. It occurs where an individual or group takes advantage of an imbalance of power to coerce, manipulate or deceive a child or young person under the age of 18 into sexual activity (a) in exchange for something the victim needs or wants, and/or (b) for the financial advantage or increased status of the perpetrator or facilitator. The victim may have been sexually exploited even if the sexual activity appears consensual. Child sexual exploitation does not always involve physical contact; it can also occur through the use of technology. (Department for Education Child Sexual Exploitation Guide 2017)

Criminal exploitation is also known as 'county lines' and is when gangs and organized crime networks exploit children to sell drugs. Often these children are made to travel across counties, and they use dedicated mobile phone ‘lines' to supply drugs
Local Safeguarding Children Partnerships (LSCP) formerly Local Safeguarding Children Boards (LSCB)

A multi-agency forum for developing, monitoring and reviewing local child protection policies and procedures and where necessary conducting Serious Case Reviews. N.B Essex Safeguarding board has retained the ESCB title but acknowledges the revised arrangements.
Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group ; Services provided by Basildon, Broomfield (Mid Essex) and Southend hospitals

Parental responsibility (PR) is defined as ‘In England and Wales, if the parents of a child are married to each other at the time of the birth, or if they have jointly adopted a child, then they both have parental responsibility. Parents do not lose parental responsibility if they divorce, and this applies to both the resident and the non-resident parent'. This is not automatically the case for unmarried parents. According to current law, a mother always has parental responsibility for her child. A father, however, has this responsibility only if he is married to the mother when the child is born or has acquired legal responsibility for his child through one of these three routes: (From 1 December 2003) by jointly registering the birth of the child with the mother. By a parental responsibility agreement with the mother. By a parental responsibility order, made by a court. Parental responsibility can only be lost where: In the case of parents their child is adopted. In the case of a person having acquired parental responsibility through a court order that order later being revoked by the court. In the case of a local authority with care order and the court later revoking the care order. In the case of a guardian where the court appoints another guardian

Sexual Assault Referral Centre (SARC) is a special facility where recent victims of rape or sexual assault can receive immediate help and support. This includes access to a forensic medical examination, which is carried out by an experienced and qualified doctor, and the opportunity to speak to the Police about what has happened to them if the client wishes to do so.

Introduced by The Children's Act (1989) is a threshold that justifies compulsory intervention into family life in the best interests of the children. Significant harm is a concept that has no absolute criteria or definition. Where the question of whether harm suffered by a child is significant, the child's health and development will be compared with that which could be reasonably expected of a similar child. Significant harm is commonly a compilation of significant events but can be a single traumatic event. Consideration should always be given to the severity of the ill treatment, duration and frequency of abuse or neglect, extent of premeditation and the presence of threat, coercion, sadism and bizarre or unusual elements. It is the responsibility of Social Services to make a judgement of whether the threshold for a Section 47 enquiry has been met (The Children's Act (1989) S31.2).

The ill treatment or the impairment of health or development. This includes for example impairment caused by seeing or hearing the mistreatment of another. “Development” means physical, emotional, behavioural or social development. “Health” includes both physical and mental health. “Ill treatment” includes sexual abuse as well as other forms of ill- treatment that are not physical.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role and Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Duties Are:
Clinical Governance Committee / In-house Safeguarding Board Meetings monitors compliance with Safeguarding;
Children policies and processes;
Site Safeguarding Children Committees / Operational meetings oversee all operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies;

The Group Integrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee is a strategic meeting to: Check and challenge that MSE systems and processes are fit for purpose to safeguard vulnerable individuals, focus on all services but not be operational, oversee CQC requirements and facilitate discussion relating to external strategic issues that may impact on the MSE group.
Chief Executive as Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust.
Chief Nurse / Chief Medical Officer –will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this policy. This includes:
When the policy is reviewed and updated incorporating the time frame for the process to be undertaken;
Reporting into the necessary governance committees;
Ensuring that MSE provides/supports the training for staff to discharge their responsibilities and that there is an appropriate competency framework to support this.
5.3.1  The Director of Nursing at SUHT also holds the executive lead in relation to Safeguarding Children.

Associate Directors of Nursing/Head of Midwifery/Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service Managers/Department Managers are responsible for the implementation of this policy at department level. This includes: Identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training; assessing service requirements against what the service is delivering.

Designated, Named Professionals and the Safeguarding Team - lead personnel have a key role in championing the importance of safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children throughout the MSE group.
MSE Safeguarding Teams:
Designated doctor;
Named doctor;
Group named nurse, safeguarding children;
Group named midwife, safeguarding children;
Specialist nurses, safeguarding children;
Specialist safeguarding midwives;
Group Associate Director and Deputy Director Safeguarding.
Other professionals who are able to provide advice and information in relation specifically to safeguarding issues are:
Paediatric Liaison Health Visitor;
Head of Paediatrics;
Head of Midwifery.

5.7.1  In the absence of the above professional, advice can be sought from senior paediatric professionals; on-call paediatric registrar and on-call Paediatrician for Child Protection via switchboard and, in addition, advice can be sought by the relevant Social Care Department.
Duties of all MSE staff (substantive or non-substantive, including volunteers) must be aware of and adhere to the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding Procedures.

5.8.1 Safeguarding is each individual employee's responsibility as set out in Working Together to Safeguarding Children (2018) and the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Interagency Child Protection and Safeguarding Procedures (2019). “All those who come into contact with children and families in their everyday work, including people who do not have a specific role in relation to child protection, have a duty to safeguard and promote the welfare of children” (What To Do If You Are Worried A Child Is Being Abused 2006).
5.8.2 Specifically all Trust staff must:
Participate in training on how to safeguard and promote the welfare of children;
Be alert to potential indicators of abuse or neglect in children;
Work effectively and liaise with professionals within the Trust and other partner agencies;
Remain professionally updated regarding safeguarding issues;
Work within the guidance from their relevant professional regulatory body.
5.8.3 Trust staff members who work predominantly or completely with adults who have parental responsibilities share a commitment to safeguard and promote the welfare of the child.
Duties of Clinical Bank and Agency Staff Working for the Trust

The MSE group is committed to professionally developing clinical bank and agency staff to take an active professional role in child protection. This development is facilitated through training and regular supervision:
Staff are expected to work within safe parameters and the NMC Code of Conduct;
To liaise with the appropriate agencies in the identification of suspected physical abuse, sexual abuse, emotional abuse and neglect and the assessment of children in need;
Bank and agency staff must work to the Trust's policies and procedures.
It is also the responsibility of the practitioner to professionally update on child protection issues and to attend mandatory and relevant study days.

Managers and Team Leaders will be responsible for monitoring the actions of their staff to safeguard and promote the welfare of children via access to supervision and personal development reviews. Children will be listened to appropriately and concerns expressed about their or any other child's welfare are taken seriously and responded to in an appropriate manner.
Main Procedural Document Points
Managing Safeguarding Concerns

If an employee of the MSE group has concerns that a child, young person or adult is at risk of harm or abuse, they should notify the local Social Services department as per MSE safeguarding policies and procedures. In addition they can discuss the case with their line manager and/or local safeguarding lead and, the person should also consider informing the local Police if applicable.
Staff should access the SET Procedures 2019 available on site intranet and consult any related guidance documents (appendix 7)
In hours the hospital safeguarding team will offer advice and additional support, and locally the Designated Professional will be available for advice and support.
Out of hours Staff may contact the Social Services Emergency Duty team, in the case of an emergency staff may consider contacting the Police.
Referral to Social Care must be made using the correct form (depending on area where child/parent lives). Referral forms and associated guidance are available on site intranet. .
Liaison with Social Care and other external agencies should occur as the need arises.
The following points should be observed:
Any Healthcare Worker making a referral should:
Where practicable, concerns should be discussed with the parent and agreement sought for a referral to children's social care unless seeking agreement is likely to:
Place the child at risk of significant harm through delay or the parent's actions or reactions;
Lead to risk of loss of evidential material (such as when there is a concern or suspicion that a serious crime such as sexual abuse or induced illness has taken place.

Where a professional does not seek parental consent to the referral the decision for this must be recorded in the child's records with the reasons, dated and signed and confirmed in the referral to children social care. A child protection referral from a professional cannot be treated as anonymous so the parent will ultimately become aware of the referrer's identity. When a parent refuses to give permission for the referral, further advice should be sought from the Safeguarding team. If having taken full account of the parent's wishes, it is still considered that there is a need for a referral:
The reason for proceeding without parental agreement must be recorded;
The parents withholding of permission must form part of the verbal and written referral to children's social care.
Practitioners working with adults must identify and record at the earliest stage:
The adult's relationship with any children;
Any parenting or caring responsibilities for children;
Which other agencies they need to work ith if they have concerns about unborn babies, children or young people.
If there are family members under 18 years old;
If family members under the age of 18 are receiving services from other
agencies, if so which ones and what is their role?
If Children's Services are involved, what is their involvement?
Is the Child on a Child Protection Plan?
Is the Child a Young Carer?
Does the service user have contact with children through their network of family
and friends?

Child Protection Information System (CP-IS) is a system dedicated to developing an information sharing process that will deliver a higher level of protection of children who visit NHS unscheduled care settings. It provides additional child protection information to staff, shares local authority information with the NHS and allows staff to deliver a higher level of child protection.
Sharing information effectively across health and care settings is vital in protecting vulnerable children and young people and preventing further harm.
CP-IS focuses on three specific categories:
Those subject to a child protection plan;
Those with ‘looked after child' status (children with full and interim care orders
and voluntary care agreements);
Any pregnant woman whose unborn child has a pre-birth child protection plan.

CP-IS has been implemented in the Emergency Department, Paediatric Assessment Unit and Maternity Services (Central Delivery Suite). If a child presents at for unscheduled care / maternity care and CP-IS identifies that a child has an allocated social worker, the social worker should be informed of attendance by the activation of the system flag (if concerns are noted a safeguarding referral should be completed).
If CP-IS does not identify the above three categories, a full risk assessment is still required and actions to safeguard if concerns are identified.

The FGM-IS is a national IT system that supports the early intervention and ongoing safeguarding of girls, under the age of 18, who have a family history of female genital mutilation (FGM). The FGM-IS is part of the NHS spine. Healthcare professionals and administrative staff can view the FGM indicator, and it can be accessed via the summary care record.

Access is controlled via NHS smartcards and the appropriate Role Based Access Codes (RBAC), so only authorised healthcare professionals and administrative staff with the relevant security permissions can access the FGM information. The alerts will be added by the child safeguarding team once notified of relevant cases. Frontline staff should discuss the provision of the alert with clients once a need is identified.
FGM-IS indicator can be viewed only in healthcare settings and does not lead to automatic information sharing with social services. Staff concerned should follow trust safeguarding procedures.

All Early Help referrals – for support services for families (Section 17 Children Act 1989) also must be referred using the appropriate form – see site intranet. For referrals in relation to an identified need for support it is important that concerns are discussed with the child and family and it is stressed to them that the referral is for support.
Consent must be obtained from the parent/carer prior to sharing information with the Social Services department.
Referrals can be completed using the relevant Early Help Assessment Form related to where child is resident or via the Essex Referral Form (Request for Support).
Please contact the Children's Safeguarding Team for further advice and guidance relating to referral for support services.

Where abuse is alleged, suspected or confirmed in a child admitted to the Trust; the child must not be discharged without the agreement of social care and police if joint investigation. Discharge should be arranged following a pre-discharge planning meeting.

Where there is a concern that a child has suffered, is suffering or at risk of suffering significant harm a strategy meeting /discussion should be convened where appropriate. If the parent or carer attempts to remove the child from the hospital before social care/ police agree staff should immediately contact the police and children's social care.
When a child presents with any injury the following must be considered:
Have you taken the history from the child?
Is the injury consistent with the injury?
Is there a delay in presentation?
Does the explanation fit with the level of the child's development?
Are there any other unexplained injuries?
Do you have any other concerns about the child?
If there are concerns:
Discuss with the Safeguarding team/Paediatrician on call;
Discuss with social care/police as indicated;
Notify the parents unless this would place the child at greater risk or there may be a loss of evidence;
Refer to the SET procedures for further guidance;
Refer to the paediatrician for further review and necessary examination;
If there is a concern about sexual abuse i.e. unexplained genital injury follows the SARC pathway;
Is there a concern about non-accidental injury; admit to hospital and follow the SET procedures.
Further investigations/examinations may be indicated dependant on clinical presentation; this may include:
Skeletal survey;
CT Scan;
Ophthalmology Examination.
If relevant, Staff should access the relevant Fracture / Injury Pathway – example appendix 4 and/or SET Bruising protocol (refer to appendix 5)

NHS Trusts have a duty to provide a safe and secure environment for patients, staff and visitors. Violent or abusive behaviour will not be tolerated; the organisation's policy is to be followed in this event. The need for parents and carers to be involved in the health care of children and young people is a basic principle of the provision of effective health care; many parents are resident on the ward with their child and should continue to provide as much care for their children as possible. However in certain circumstances it may not be appropriate for parents to care for their child because:
A safety plan is in place that requires the parent/carer to be supervised which would be agreed by the parents with parental responsibility;
The parents/carer are implicated in an on-going section 47 investigation and require supervision until the outcome can be concluded and risks identified.
There are identified child protection concerns which require the parent/carer to be continually supervised;
There are restrictions to visiting /contacting the child laid down by a court order.
In addition to the above there may be restrictions imposed by the court on a parent/carers access to their partner e.g. an injunction.

The purpose of parental supervision is to ensure safety whilst enabling the child to have contact with parents, carers and family members. It is the responsibility of children's social care to organise and fund child protection supervision. If they are unable to provide a staff member, then the social worker must identify either an agency social worker or another family member who is able to undertake safe supervised contact between parent and child. It is not possible for hospital staff to be responsible for carrying out any supervisory responsibilities

Where there is professional disagreement about whether or not a parent/carer needs to be supervised, concerns should be escalated within the individual organisations in accordance with the guidance in SET procedures/Professional disagreement flowchart

At any point in the process when there is reasonable cause to suspect that a child has suffered or is likely to suffer significant harm and therefore meeting the section 47 threshold for strategy discussion should be convened. This discussion must involve Children's Social Care, the police and other relevant agencies such as health.

This may be as soon as a referral has been made. The purpose is to share information in order to decide whether Section 47 enquiries should be initiated or continued, plan how these should be handled including action required immediately to safeguard the child.

Staff (whether working with the child or adult who is a parent /carer) who are invited to attend a Child Protection Conference/Professional meeting due to their professional involvement must ensure they attend when invited. Should an invited professional be unable to attend, apologies must be communicated and a suitable deputy found

It is essential that a written report regarding their involvement with and knowledge of, the family, including identification of risk factors and protective practice should be prepared for the Conference. The report should identify current health status and any outstanding health need. Pre-Conference supervision can be sought via the Safeguarding Team and guidance regarding report writing can be given.
The Safeguarding Team will inform professionals of the invitation to Conference via email – it is then the responsibility of the professional to submit a report / arrange attendance at Conference

Information contained in the report should be routinely shared with family members prior to the conference. Any concerns about sharing information with parents or carers should be discussed with the conference chair prior to the conference taking place. If the health professional has not been able to share their report with the family, reasons for this should be clearly stated on the report before submission

Where a practitioner is identified as a member of a core group for a child who is made subject to a child protection plan at the conference, they must prioritise attendance at core group meetings. The core group is responsible for developing and implementing the Child Protection Plan. Additional advice and support can be provided by MSE Named and Specialist Professionals.

If the decision of the Conference is taken that the child is at continuing risk of significant harm then they will become subject to a Child Protection Plan. They will be included in one or more of the following categories: physical abuse; sexual abuse; emotional abuse or neglect. Relevant professionals should be informed of the outcome of the Child Protection Conference.

If the core assessment under Section 47 of the Children Act gives rise to concerns that an unborn child may be at future risk of significant harm, Children's Social Care may decide to convene an Initial Child Protection Conference prior to the child's birth.

In the event the allocated midwife is unable to attend and cover cannot be sought with the area team – the Named Midwife for Safeguarding/member of the Safeguarding Children team can attend and present the compiled report on behalf of the midwife

A Hospital Pre-discharge Planning Meeting must be held whenever a professional or agency has raised child protection concerns for a child admitted to hospital or when the child/unborn baby are the subjects of a Child Protection Plan.
The purpose of the Pre-Discharge Planning Meeting is to:
Consider medical and social reports about the cause of concern;

Consider the social work / multi-agency assessment/s of the risks to and the needs of the child, including ‘home safety' informed (wherever practicable) by a home visit by a Social Worker the results of which are shared at the meeting;
Consider the needs / risks in relation to other children in the family;
Clarify on-going medical care;
Identify support needed for those caring for the child once discharged;
Formulate a multi-agency plan on discharge from hospital to address the risks /
concerns raised in respect of the child;

An assessment of risk must be concluded before the child/ren is / are ready for discharge; a Pre-discharge Planning Meeting will normally be convened within 24 hours of it being called. This narrow time-frame requires a high level of flexibility and co-operation between professionals;

The Safeguarding Team will usually act as Chair for these meetings. It is also essential that accurate minutes are taken. All agencies working with the family should be invited i.e. health visitor, school nurse, midwife if applicable.

When a child is suspected to be suffering or likely to suffer significant harm, Children's Social Care are required to make enquires to decide what action they should take to safeguard and promote the child's welfare. These are known as Section 47 enquiries.

The Children Act places a statutory duty on other agencies, including health, to help Children's Social Care with these enquiries. Section 17 enquiries involve the sharing of information but require the consent of the parent. MSE safeguarding teams process all such enquiries.

A child protection examination is carried out to look for signs that a child or young person has been abused or neglected. Referrals from Children's Social Care for child protection medical examination across MSE will be made to the Paediatric consultant on call. Staff are advised to follow the relevant site Procedure for Organising and Undertaking Child Protection Medical Assessments.
The preliminary report is to be provided to Social Care within 24 hours/one working day.
The final written report is to be provided to Social Care within the agreed timescale.
Fabricated or induced illness (FII) is a complex issue and individual suspected cases typically require a lot of consideration and discussion before they are to be regarded in child protection terms.

The characteristics of fabricated or induced illness are a lack of the usual corroboration of findings with symptoms or signs, or – in circumstances of proven organic illness – lack of the usual response to proven effective treatments.
There are three main ways of fabricating or inducing illness in a child. More than one may be evident in individual cases: fabrication of signs and symptoms, including:
Fabrication of past medical history;
Fabrication of signs and symptoms;
Falsification of hospital charts and records, and specimens of bodily fluids. This may also include falsification of letters and documents inducement of illness by a variety of means.

The signs and symptoms require careful medical evaluation for a range of possible diagnoses. Parents should be kept informed of findings from any medical evaluation, but at no time should concerns about reasons for child's signs and symptoms be shared with the parents if this information would jeopardize the child's safety.
For guidance on the Management of Children in whom illness is fabricated or induced refer to the SET procedures (2019)
(Refer to Appendix 6)
Female genital mutilation (FGM) comprises all procedures involving the partial or total removal of the female external genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons.

There are four types of FGM, ranging from a symbolic prick to the vagina to the fairly extensive removal and narrowing of the vagina opening. In the UK all forms of FGM are prevalent. FGM is also sometimes known as ‘female genital cutting' or ‘female circumcision'. However, circumcision is not an appropriate term. Communities tend to use local names for referring to this practice including “sunna”.

Health staff are in a key position to identify girls who may be visiting overseas and may be at risk of FGM. FGM is considered child abuse in the UK and a grave violation of the human rights of girls and women.
Practice points:
‘Aiding, abetting and counselling applies to those who assist or persuade a girl to perform FGM on herself even though it is not itself an offence for that child to carry it out on herself;

‘Girl includes woman' (Female Genital Mutilation Act, 2003) although not an offence for a girl or young woman to perform FGM on herself, consideration should be given to whether such self-harm is a safeguarding issue where the action may be the result of adult pressure;
Midwives need to note that it is illegal to reinfibulate a woman following the birth of her baby;

Midwives and Obstetricians may become aware that FGM has taken place when treating a pregnant woman. This should trigger concern for any female child of the family and should be reported to the Safeguarding Children Team;
All incidents of FGM must be recorded on the patient's records and recorded on the dataset as per national guidance.
What to do if you suspect a child may be at risk of undergoing FGM:
Be aware that FGM is child abuse and that you must take action;
Any concerns a child may have / or be about to undergo FGM must be discussed with the Safeguarding Team and reported to Children's Social care/Police as per trust policy.
(This Guidance should be read in conjunction with organisation FGM Policy and the SET procedures)

Working Together to Safeguard Children (2018) identifies potential reasons why a child/young person may self-harm; the document specifically discusses ‘sexual abuse; forced marriage; being bullied and witnessing domestic abuse' which may all be linked to the self-harming behaviour. The safeguarding referral is important given that for each child that takes their own life there will be between 40 and a hundred others who have self-harmed (Fox and Horton, 2004).

Issues of confidentiality are particularly challenging with children and young people who self-harm and have capacity yet refuse the involvement of their parents or carers in their treatment or refuse consent to disclose issues relating to their safety to their parents or carers. In these circumstances healthcare professionals need to carefully weigh the rights of the young person to confidentiality and the risk to the therapeutic relationship of a breach of confidentiality against providing the family and carers with sufficient information to enable them to appropriately protect and care for the young person.

A risk assessment should be completed and should include a holistic assessment of the family, their social situation, family history and any potential child protection issues. If the young person discloses abuse or neglect safeguarding procedures must be followed.

If an expectant mother has a prior history of self-harm this may be exacerbated during pregnancy; concerns need to be raised in consideration of the unborn baby (The Royal College of Midwives, 2009). In such cases a safeguarding referral should always be completed and/or advice should be sought from the Named Midwife and Specialist Midwives for Mental Health.
Child Sexual Exploitation and Criminal Exploitation

Sexually exploitation of children is child sexual abuse and often involves physical and emotional abuse; it may also be a significant feature in neglect. As a result of recent national cases CSE has become a priority for health professionals and organisations. It is therefore essential that all healthcare professionals are aware of the range of presentations; staff should be alert and competent to identify and act upon concerns that a child is at risk of or experiencing abuse through sexual exploitation.
(This Guidance should be read in conjunction with; https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_d ata/file/591903/CSE_Guidance_Core_Document_13.02.2017.pdf)
If a child presents to MSE for Sexual Health Services, Gynaecology or Midwifery services and they are under the age of 16 years please refer to the SET procedures for further guidance.
Midwives are advised to refer any on-going pregnancy to children's social care when the mother is 16 or under. Any girl, who is pregnant, must be offered specialist support and guidance.

Young people under the age of 13 years: If the allegation concerns penetrative sex, or other intimate sexual activity, this could be considered statutory rape as it is presumed that the child does not have the capacity to consent. This requires a referral to Children's Social Care and a strategy discussion may be held. The SARC pathway should be followed.
In cases of suspected sexual abuse the case should always be discussed with a senior colleague, before considering any further physical or verbal examinations.

Examinations following child sexual abuse suspicions will normally be co-ordinated and arranged by the local SARC, and conducted by a professional who has appropriate training and has been approved by the designated/named doctor.

In all CSA suspicions or allegations, children's social care should be informed. They will take responsibility for arranging a planning/strategy meeting if appropriate. This may be held without the knowledge or involvement of the parents/carers, as it is important not to alert an alleged perpetrator at this stage. The planning meeting ensures that both the police and social care undertake a coordinated investigation.

Children can be placed at harm from gang activity both through participation in and as a victim of gang violence; this can be in relation to their peers or to a member of their family household who is involved in gang activity. A child who is affected by gang activity or serious youth crime may have suffered or may be likely to suffer significant harm through physical, sexual and emotional abuse.
(This Guidance should be read in conjunction with the MSE Policy for Child sexual Exploitation and Criminal Exploitation and the SET procedures)
Health professionals should be aware of the need to support parents to keep their children safe when using online, mobile technologies and to protect them from cyber bullying.

Increasingly, it is recognised that solely attempting to block or rigorously control access to undesirable content is ineffectual and counter-productive, encouraging some young people to find ways round the rules and limiting the use of potentially valuable materials and activities to underpin learning and development.

Local Safeguarding Children partnerships have an important role in co-coordinating and ensuring the effectiveness of local work to safeguard and promote the welfare of children. Guidance is available on the ESCB website.
http://www.escb.co.uk/en-gb/workingwithchildren/policiesandguidance.aspx

Radicalisation is defined as the process by which people come to support terrorism and extremism and, in some cases, to then participate in terrorist activity. Extremism is vocal or active opposition to fundamental British values including democracy, the rule of law, individual liberty and mutual respect and tolerance of different faiths and beliefs.

Health care professionals may treat children who are vulnerable to radicalisation. The key challenge for the health sector is to ensure that, where there are signs that someone has been or is being drawn into terrorism, the health care workers can interpret those signs correctly, are aware of the support that is available and are confident in referring the child for further support (HM Government 2011)

The issue of children with domestic abuse and violence is now recognised as a matter for concern in its own right by both government and key children's services. Domestic abuse includes Forced marriage; Honour based abuse and Female Genital mutilation.

Positive outcomes can be adversely affected for a child living with domestic abuse; the impact is usually on every aspect of a child's life. The impact of domestic abuse on an individual child will vary according to the child's resilience and the strengths and weaknesses of their particular circumstances.
MSE staff are in a position to identify or receive a disclosure about domestic abuse; where routine enquiry has been introduced staff must provide the opportunity for the patient to be seen alone.
The central imperatives of any intervention for children living with domestic abuse are to:
Protect the children;
Support the carer (non-abusive partner) to protect themselves and their children.
If there a concern about the risk of significant harm to the child/ren then Trust staff have a duty to protect the child/ren; a referral to children's social care must be made
(Please also refer to organisation's domestic abuse policy)
Children Not Brought to Appointments

Research has identified that a failure to attend appointments is a significant factor in many serious case reviews (Review of Serious Case Reviews, DCSF 2009); it may be an indication that the parents/carers are failing to engage with health professionals with a consequence that the child's health needs are not being met (Refer to organisation's Policy for the Management of Children that are not Brought to Appointments)
Record Keeping

Record keeping is a key foundation of safeguarding processes; this forms a critical cornerstone of any communication enabling multi-agency working. It is important all entries are signed and status of whoever wrote the respective entry being clearly recorded along with the time and date.

31.2.1 Staff must at all times maintain awareness that records may be used within any subsequent investigation/judicial processes, thus staff will ensure that records contain substantial issues linked to any allegations.

31.2.2 All records should be evidence based and factual, in line with NMC Record Keeping Guidance (2015). Any safeguarding consideration must be referred to the Local Authority Children's Services as a priority and trust safeguarding procedures observed.
31.2.4 The hospital health record must evidence:
The reason for concern;
Observations made by the practitioner to support their concern;
Contextual information e.g. presence of a learning disability, mental health or substance misuse or any communication difficulties;
Documentation any imminent risks;
If there may be an allegation of a criminal nature - confirmation that the police have been notified.
31.2.5 Child protection documentation received from other agencies is filed in the child's medical record (or maternal record in case of an unborn) and uploaded onto CED / EPR/ Lorenzo.
31.2.6 Alerts to child protection concerns are placed on Medway/Lorenzo. Staff should seek clarification required relating to the nature of the alert from the safeguarding children team.
Information Sharing

It is important that all involved remain confident that their personal information is kept safe and secure and that practitioners maintain the privacy rights of the individual, whilst sharing information to deliver better services. It is important that practitioners can share information appropriately as part of their day-to-day practice and do so confidently.

31.3.1 Staff should ensure they are familiar with trust's information governance policy and have undertaken mandatory information governance training. This will clarify what information is appropriate to share. Local safeguarding Children Safeguarding partnerships (LSCP) will have multi-agency information sharing policies/protocols in place and staff should ensure they understand and adhere to these.
(Refer to organisation's policies on Data Protection and Code of Confidentiality Policy for full guidance)

31.3.2 Good information sharing is at the heart of good safeguarding practice. The area is covered by legislation, principally the Data Protection Act 1998, and by court decisions on issues of confidentiality and privacy. At its heart is the principle that information should be shared if that helps to protect children or adults, or to prevent a crime.
31.3.3 There are seven golden rules for information sharing:
Remember that the Data protection Act 1998 is not a barrier to sharing information;
Keep a record of your decision and the reasons for it. Record what you have shared, with whom and for what purpose;

Be open and honest with the person (and/or their family where appropriate) at the outset about why, what, how and with whom information will, or could be shared, and seek their agreement, unless it is unsafe or inappropriate to do so;
Seek advice if you are in any doubt, without disclosing the identity of the person where possible;

Share with consent where appropriate and, where possible, respect the wishes of those who do not consent to share confidential information. You may still share information without consent if, in your judgement, that lack of consent can be overridden in public interest. You will need to base your judgement on the facts of the case;
Consider safety and well-being of the person and others who may be affected by their actions;
Necessary, proportionate, relevant, accurate, timely and secure.

31.3.4 Reasons for decisions to share, or not share must be recorded in the medical record. Decisions require professional, informed judgment. If in doubt this should be discussed with a named professional for safeguarding / member of the safeguarding team or you may need to seek advice from MSE's legal representatives.

In the event there is a concern about any safeguarding children incidents i.e. hospital policy not being followed in order to safeguard a child a Datix form should be completed. This will be reviewed in accordance with Trust policy.
Any safeguarding issue that may attract media interest should be shared with the Director of Nursing so that they are able to brief the executive team as required.

The MSE Group is committed to have arrangements in place to ensure effective training of all staff. MSE expects all their staff to be trained in children and adult safeguarding at level 1 as a minimum, further levels of training will be determined by the responsibilities set out in job descriptions/role functions.

Support, supervision and mentorship will be provided for safeguarding leads within MSE as appropriate and identified through personal development needs. Line managers will agree the level of safeguarding training required for each employee depending on their role and responsibilities, in line with the intercollegiate guidance for children (2019).

Further guidance regarding levels of safeguarding training for professionals can be accessed via the intercollegiate guidance document; Safeguarding Children and Young People: Roles and Competencies for Healthcare Staff , Fourth Edition:2019

All NHS services are required to fulfil their legal duty under section 11 of the Children Act 2004 and statutory responsibilities as set out in Working Together (2018) .Working Together (2018) and the Accountability and Assurance Framework (2018) outlines that safeguarding supervision should be an integral part of practice for all health care practitioners but particularly for named and designated professionals within their role of supporting other professionals in their agencies to recognise the risk to children .

As a minimum case holding staff will receive Safeguarding Children supervision every three months but more frequently if required. For key clinical groups inclusive of Paediatric, Neonatal, Children's Services and Paediatric Emergency Department

- safeguarding supervision will be offered at a minimum of four times per year. It is expected that staff working within these groups will attend safeguarding supervision no less than two times per year but more frequently if required. Following specific case supervision – a record of the supervisory discussion along with a plan of action will be recorded on the child or expectant's mother's electronic/paper record to ensure other practitioners are made aware of any concerns.
(Refer to Intercollegiate Document Safeguarding Competencies for Healthcare Staff /MSE Safeguarding Supervision Policy for full guidance)
Wherever children are seen in the hospital for assessment and/or treatment there must be a second person present to act as a chaperone thus ensuring the child is safe at all times.
(Refer to organisation's policy relating to chaperoning for full guidance)

A young person under 16 years may consent to medical treatment if he/she is judged to be competent to give that consent. It is considered good practice for doctors and other health professionals to follow the criteria outlined by Lord Fraser in 1985, in the House of Lord's ruling in the case of Victoria Gillick v West Norfolk
and Wisbech Health Authority and Department of Health and Social Security. These are commonly known as the Fraser Guidelines: (Refer to Appendix – 2 and 8 for Fraser
guideline and consent flowchart)
In England and Wales the term “Looked after” is defined in law under the Children Act 1989. Looked after children fall into four main groups;
Children who are accommodated under voluntary agreement with their parents (Section 20);
Children who are subject to a care order (Section 31) or an interim care order (section 38);
Children who are subject to emergency care orders for their protection (Section 44 and 46);
Children who are compulsorily accommodated; this includes children remanded to the local authority or subject to a criminal justice supervision order with a residence requirement (section21).
The term also applies to children who are:
Unaccompanied asylum seekers or those trafficked from abroad;
Children in family and friends placements;
Children where the agency has the authority to place the child for adoption;
It does not apply to children who have been adopted or who are on a special guardianship order.

Most children become looked after as a result of poverty, abuse and neglect. Although they have the same health needs as their peers the extent of these is often greater because of their past experiences; evidence suggests that care leavers have poorer outcomes than the general population, particularly in relation to educational attainment, homelessness and mental health.

The MSE Group has a statutory role in ensuring that arrangements are in place to meet the health needs of Looked after Children. Within MSE Looked after children should be able to participate in decisions about their health care. The MSE Group seeks to promote a culture where:

Looked after children are listened to; staf should take account of their views according to their age and understanding; they should be provided with the information they need to make informed decisions about their health needs;

Staff are able to identify and respond to their physical, emotional and mental health needs without making the child or young person feel different. 13.6 When looked after children move placement into Mid Essex and are currently receiving or on a waiting list for health services, their treatment should continue uninterrupted; services should not be refused on the basis that the placement may be short term or unplanned. Looked after children should be seen without delay and wait no-longer than a child in the local area with an equivalent need who requires an equivalent service.

Health professionals who provide care to children and young people who are looked after should have the appropriate skills and competences and should receive continuing professional development; these are outlined within the Royal Colleges Intercollegiate document; this can lead to improved outcomes for children and young people.
Any concern about Looked after children should be directed to the Safeguarding Team who will provide further advice and support or communicated directly to the allocated Social Worker.

A private fostering arrangement is one made without the involvement of Children's Social Care for the care of a child under the age of 16 (under 18, if disabled) by someone other than a parent or close relative for 28 days or more. This may include children sent from abroad, asylum seeking and refugee children, teenagers staying in short term arrangements with friends or other non-relatives and language students with host families.

Under the Children Act 1989 private foster carers and those with parental responsibility are respectively required to notify the local authority of their intention to privately foster or have a child fostered. Health professionals should notify Children's Social Care of any private fostering arrangements that come to their attention; unless they are satisfied that Children's Social Care has been notified of the arrangement.

This law is designed to empower and protect any vulnerable person aged 16 and over, who is not able to make decisions at a particular time because of illness, injury, a disability or the effects of drugs or alcohol.

(For further information and guidance on the systems and processes in operation at the organisation to be used when the powers of the Mental Capacity Act are invoked the MSE MCA policies can be accessed on the Trust Website)
Working Together to Safeguard Children (DOH 2018) states that the LSCP's should consider a case review for every case where abuse or neglect is known or suspected and either:
A child dies; or
A child is seriously harmed and there are concerns as to the way in which the local authority, their safeguarding partnership or other relevant persons have worked together to safeguard the child.
The purpose is to:
Establish whether there are lessons to be learned from the case about the way in which local professionals and agencies work together to safeguard children;
Identify clearly what those lessons are, how they will be acted upon, and
What is expected to change as a result; and as a consequence, and
To improve inter-agency working and better safeguard children.

In MSE if a CSPR is being considered where there has been involvement either with the child or parent or other relevant family member, the organisation will be required to participate in the review process. Any professional may be required to contribute to both the Trust and LSCP review process. The chief executive is the person initially informed. They will then inform the MSE Named Nurse, who is responsible for facilitating and advising on requirements for serious case reviews for the Trust.

The named professional/s / review team will follow the MSE / Local procedures for structured investigations and will follow the LSCP terms of reference for the review process. The MSE investigation team will conduct the IMR (internal management review) which will inform the LSCP and will consider the level of internal investigation required.

The final recommendations and action plans from review panels are considered by the Group Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee who may take a lead on some actions that require a Trust wide response, for example child protection structures and arrangements, Trust wide policy, training programmes and systems.

Recruiting managers shall seek guidance from Human Resources, to determine the level of DBS (formerly CRB) check required for the role. The manager shall ensure clearance is obtained before the applicant commences employment. As an employer of staff in a ‘regulated activity' MSE has a responsibility to refer concerns to the DBS in accordance with the Safeguarding Vulnerable Groups Act 2006. Managers must report concerns to their local HR team, who should seek advice from the MSE Safeguarding leads, or directly through the Local Authority Designated Officer (LADO)

Any complaints made against MSE staff by service users/members of the public must be investigated. Where a member of staff working within MSE becomes aware of or witness an allegation/incident of abuse against a child this must be immediately reported.
Concerns of a suspected/actual abuse should be raised with the line manager immediately and an incident form completed along with a referral to children's services.

Staff members against whom allegations of child abuse have been raised will be managed through the trusts HR/Disciplinary procedures, and a full investigation will follow. The Police will also always be involved to ensure transparency, and that any potential criminal offence is pursued.

The MSE Group should work closely with the Local Authority Designated Officer (LADO) to ensure that any allegation of abuse is dealt with fairly, quickly and consistently to provide effective protection for the child and at the same time supports the member of staff subject to the allegation.
An allegation may require consideration from any of the following inter-related perspectives:
Child protection enquiries by Children's Social Care;
Criminal Investigation by the Police;
Staff disciplinary procedures;
Complaints procedures.
(This Guidance should be read in conjunction with the Organisation's Allegations Against Staff Policies and Procedure and the SET procedures)
Difference of Opinion between Healthcare Professionals

On occasion health professionals may have a difference of opinion which means that it is difficult to plan how to proceed with a particular case, if the differences cannot be resolved between the individuals concerned and there are safeguarding implications then the different views should in the first instance be discussed with the relevant named professionals for child safeguarding. If the issue cannot be resolved then the Group Named Nurse for Child Safeguarding should be involved and a plan agreed as to how best the differences should be resolved. This may require the involvement of an external third party.
Dissent Following Referral to Social Care

Social Care should notify professional within one working day regarding their decision in relation to intervention for the child and family. If the healthcare worker disagrees with the decision and believes that this places the child at further risk of significant harm the Safeguarding Children Team should be contacted and any issues raised.
Dissent at Child Protection Conference

If the Conference Chair is unable to achieve a consensus as to whether or not the child should be made subject to a Child Protection Plan she/he will note any dissenting views within the Child Protection Conference minutes. If the professional believes that the decision made by the Conference Chair places the child at further risk of signification harm it is expected that concerns will be discussed with the Children's Safeguarding Team to ensure any appropriate action is taken as required.

43.3.1 Designated professionals should be made aware of any professional or interagency disagreements. If the matter cannot be resolved by mediation then the SET/CCG Escalation Procedures must be used (flow chart) – Appendix 3
Difference of Opinion – between Agencies

If staff become concerned about the lack of response to a safeguarding concern from any agency it should be discussed with a member of the safeguarding team/safeguarding lead that will escalate it, as appropriate, in line with SET Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures. These can be found here: http://www.escb.co.uk/media/1670/set-procedures-oct-2018-updated.pdf

Appendix 2: Fraser Guidelines
Fraser guidelines, Gillick competence are terms that are often as substitutes for each other, as if they were interchangeable rather than two distinct but related terms.

Consent is required before medical treatment is commenced on a patient. Without the consent of the patient a criminal offence is committed and the patient may bring a civil action against the health‐care professional who initiated the treatment. There are, of course, provisions within English law that when a patient is unable to consent, treatment may be provided in their best interests without subjecting the health‐care professional to criminal or civil liability.
The fact that a patient is a child (under 18 yrs old) does not remove the requirement for consent.
Gillick competency (1985)

Gillick competence refers to the fact that some children under the age of 16 are able to give consent. The key to whether the child can give consent is their emotional and intellectual maturity and their ability to understand the proposed treatment. Those children who are deemed by the health‐care professional to be Gillick competent are the ones who can provide consent for the proposed treatment.

Although the Gillick case was concerned with contraceptive advice and treatment for girls under 16, the principle that a child under 16 can consent to treatment on their own behalf has been extended to boys, and to treatment and advice other than for contraception
Fraser guidelines

Fraser guidelines refer to a specific set of guidelines that Lord Fraser proposed in the Gillick case. The guidelines state that contraceptive advice or treatment can be provided to a child under 16 without parental consent or knowledge provided that the health‐care professional is satisfied:

Although initially confined to contraceptive advice and treatment, Fraser guidelines can now be extended to cover abortion and sexually transmitted infections, as both these require that the girl is having sexual intercourse, a key aspect of the guideline.

It should be noted that the first point in the Fraser guidelines, that of understanding, may refer to the process of determining Gillick competence and it can then be seen that the two terms are not interchangeable. Rather, they are two different concepts:
*Fraser guidelines referring to specific guidance that must be followed by the health‐care professional to provide specific treatment to a child;
*Gillick competence referring to the ability of the child to give consent.

Resolving health professional difference of opinion
Avoid Professional disputes that lose sight of the child, by resolving conflict urgently.
Discussion between the professionals involved to resolve the difference of opinion for no longer than 5 working days.
If not resolved – Discuss with Line Manager/Consultant Paediatrician and /or Named Doctor /Nurse/ for Safeguarding
If unresolved escalate to Senior Managers, Safeguarding Managers, Designated Nurse/ Doctor. Escalation should be documented, timely and child focused.
If not resolved – Escalate to the Medical Director / Executive Lead for Safeguarding
All discussions and decisions should be documented in the child's notes
Appendix  - Fracture Pathway
It usually takes considerable force to produce a fracture in a child or infant Fractures require appropriate explanation, consistent with child's developmental age
Physical abuse should always be considered when an infant (under 18 months) presents with fracture with no clear history of trauma
Careful history: avoid leading questions and do not offer any options or suggestions about how child could have sustained injuries
Family history: history of osteogenesis imperfecta or recurrent fractures
Birth history: mode of delivery. Birth related fractures usually heal within few weeks after birth and calcification is visible within 11-14 days
History to suggest risk of osteopenia: prematurity, chronic illness, severe failure to thrive
Examine the child carefully for other external injuries – document all bruises or lack of as these may not be visible after a cast is applied.
Age of child
The younger the child the greater the likelihood of abuse—80% of abused children with fractures are <18 months, 85% of accidental fractures occur in children > 5 years of age
Fractures  in Infants    months or non  -mobile, are  more  likely  to  have  been caused  non accidentally
Type of fracture:
Child with rib fracture has a 7 in 10 chance of being physically abused
Child with femoral fracture has 1 in 3 chance of being abused
Child under 3 yrs. of age with humerus fracture has 1 in 2 chance of being abused An infant with skull fracture has 1 in 3 chance of being abused
When to be concerned about fractures in children
Fractures in children less than 18 months of age
Multiple fractures, especially of varying ages
Rib fractures without underlying bone disease or major trauma, especially if there are multiple rib fractures
Femoral fractures— Suspicious unless proven otherwise - more suspicious if child not independently mobile and/or under 18 months of age
Spine — often abusive and often missed – especially consider in head injury
Humerus fractures – Mid shaft, spiral and oblique fractures are strongly linked with physical abuse. Any other fracture except supracondylar fractures is suspicious

Metaphyseal Fractures are more commonly described in physical child abuse than in non-abuse. Classical Metaphyseal lesions will only be found if rigorous radiological techniques are applied. Metaphyseal fractures have been frequently described in fatal abuse.

Skull Fracture requires considerable force and often seen in young children. Linear and parietal fractures commonest both in accidental and non- accidental type. Multiple and bilateral fractures crossing the midline, more commonly associated with abuse.
Tibia and Fibula fractures - The presence of tibia/fibula fractures in a child aged less than 18 months is strongly associated with child abuse.
Other Fractures - Vertebral, pelvic, hands, feet and sternal fractures occur in physical abuse: appropriate radiology is required for detection.
PRACTICE GUIDANCE
Discuss these cases with senior practitioner in your area
Refer children with the above fractures or any other fractures without clear explanation to on-call Paediatric team
Child should not be discharged from ED without seeing a Paediatric Registrar or Consultant.
Explain the reason for your concerns and referral to parents and document the discussion
The child might need a detailed assessment including blood tests, skeletal survey and CT scan of head as indicated
If the injury is inadequately explained or unexplained / concerns regarding non accidental injury – the case should be discussed with children's social care and formal referral made.

The referral to social care MUST be done at the same time that the referral is made to Paediatric team. This enables social care to do an initial assessment and attend the detailed assessment done by Paediatric team if needed.
Making a safeguarding referral is everyone's responsibility and should be done by the professional identifying the concerns. This discussion must be recorded in the case notes.
Verbal referrals to social care must be followed up in writing within 24 hours
